case_vignette: A 40-year-old woman visits her physician’s office with her husband. Her husband says that she has been complaining of recurring headaches over the past few months. A year ago she was diagnosed with diabetes and is currently on treatment for it. About 6 months ago, she was diagnosed with high blood pressure and is also taking medication for it. Her husband is concerned about the short span during which she has been getting all these symptoms. He also says that she occasionally complains of changes and blurring in her vision. In addition to all these complaints, he has observed changes in her appearance, more prominently her face. Her forehead and chin seem to be protruding more than usual.
question: Suspecting a hormonal imbalance, which  initial tests would the physician order to indicate a possible diagnosis?

My husband didn't mention anything about a family history of thyroid disease or autoimmune disorders.

My husband didn't mention if the headaches are associated with any specific time of day, activity, or environments.

We didn't talk about whether the headaches are on one side or all over, or about nausea or vomiting.

I haven't mentioned having an eye exam recently for the vision problems.

Given the information provided and without more specific details to address other potential causes, it is difficult to make a definitive diagnosis. Please consult a healthcare professional for a thorough examination and appropriate diagnostic tests.

There is uncertainty about any recent changes in her medication or dosage. There is no mention of any family history of thyroid disease or autoimmune disorders. There is no information provided about any potential stress or emotional disturbances that may be contributing to her symptoms. The patient has not had an eye exam recently for the vision problems.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The physician would likely order serum cortisol, ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) levels, and possibly a dexamethasone suppression test, in addition to a glucose tolerance test and MRI or CT scan of the pituitary gland to evaluate for possible acromegaly or Cushing's syndrome.

Given your symptoms of recurring headaches, blurry vision, changes in facial features, and pre-existing diabetes, I recommend that you undergo an MRI of your brain to evaluate for any abnormalities in your pituitary gland.
